p: Figure 24 and Figure 25 display microstructural images depending on the cooling rate in Al0.72Si. Optical microscopy after very slow cooling with 10 −4 K/s ( Figure 24) reveals polygonal-shaped Si particles. If cooling is carried out ten times faster, at 10 −3 K/s, the number of quench-induced particles is substantially increased ( Figure 24B), while their particle size is reduced. From Figure 23, it can be seen that the volume fraction of quench-induced precipitation is similar for these two very slow cooling rates. In Ref. [ 117, 132] we demonstrated that these polygonal-shaped precipitates originate from the HTRs seen in cooling DSC. At a cooling rate of 10 −2 K/s, quench-induced particles are further reduced in size. A detailed analysis of the OM images reveals that next to the polygonal-shaped particles, further plate-like particles (appearance: needle or rod-shaped) with distinct orientations appear (see also Figure 26). It has been proven that these plate-shaped particles originate from the LTRs [ 117, 132]. After cooling at 1 K/s, no quench-induced precipitates can be seen in OM. Figure 25 demonstrates that the vast majority of quench-induced precipitates form inside the grains. In high-purity alloys such as this one, grains are generally coarse. The OM results are consistent with the DSC results in Figure 22, indicating that at 0.01 K/s, the HTR has already been suppressed to a great extent. However, at this cooling rate, and for even faster cooling at 0.1 K/s, TEM unambiguously shows that some precipitates form during the quench (see Figure 27 and Figure 28).
